Michael LÃ©pine wrote:

> If this has only happened once, then the data or initialization is suspect.
> The good thing about software is that it is consistent.

Perhaps I was overreacting, but, nevertheless it still completely escapes
me how it could happen in any normal circumstances, unless there is
something peculiar about JUnit classes, but I wasn't using them
at the time.

> I'm not being smart.
> What I'm saying is this, somehow the data or some initialization step
> affected the testing so that you got this exception. I don't think it is a
> quirk in the Vector class itself. You can always check the class by looking
> at the source for Vector if you want to make sure though (I'm too lazy to do
> it right now myself :).
>
> Hope this helps to guide your efforts.

I will just have to assume (and hope) that some weird,
unlikely-to-be-repeated, event
occurred at the time.

FYI, here's a copy of the Vector source code. (Although I can't
say if it's the same one that I am using.) This source code doesn't
seem to shed much light. Anyhow, please don't put yourself to
any more trouble over this. Thanks again.

public synchronized Object remove(int index) {
modCount++;
if (index >= elementCount)
throw new ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException(index);
Object oldValue = elementData[index];

int numMoved = elementCount - index - 1;
if (numMoved > 0)
System.arraycopy(elementData, index+1, elementData, index,
numMoved);
elementData[--elementCount] = null; // Let gc do its work

return oldValue;
}
